Posts.Content: I thought this article may be of help for people considering a PET Scan. https://pcnrv.blogspot.ca/2016/12/pe...te-cancer.html
Posts.Signature: Age 66, DOB 1950. No PC in family history. VERY athletic, 5'10", 170 lbs, retired, non smoker, occaisional drinker. PSA 09/2013 8.1, 04/2014 8.4, 08/2014 9.4, 12/2014 8.8, 06/2015 8.7, 06/2016 11.2. DRE enlarged but no lumps. Biopsy 07/14/2016 6 sites, adenocarcinoma in 6 of 12 cores (surf involv % 2, 15, 60, 40, 10, 3). Gleason 4+3=7. Clinical stage T1c. Bone and CT scans both negative. Open RP 10/24/2016. Staples out Nov 4 2016. Catheter out Nov 7 2016. Pathology post op Nov 10 2016 Specimen weight 81 grams. Measurements in cm 4.0 x 4.7 x 4.1 Gleason downgrade from 4+3 to 3+4 Percent of prostate involved by tumor 6.30 Staging is pT3/pN0 Extraprostatic extension present, nonfocal (established, extensive), right side Apical resection margin is bilaterally involved by invasive carcinoma Right and left seminal vesicles not involved by adenocarcinoma Lymph nodes 3 right and 2 left negative PSA 6 weeks after surgery 0.53 PSA 10 weeks after surgery 0.65
Posts.Title: PET Scans PET/CT PET/MRI

Posts.Content: Got lucky! Was in the bathroom cleaning up with my gown off. Felt the urge, sat on the toilet and had an easy soft BM. So I will get real food today. Yippee! And thanks for the encouragement.

Posts.Title: Had my ORP yesterday...

Posts.Content: Thanks for the well wishes. Luck may have run out though. My nurse came to pull the drain out. You guys never warned me about this! She took the stitch out then said take a deep breath then gave it a pull. It did not budge, but hurt like heck. Tried a second pull, still no luck and it hurt worse. Then she went and got a bigger nurse. Well, a more expierienced nurse, but she was bigger. New nurse looked me in the eye, because she new what was coming, then she got it out. Ouch! Now to get the bladder spasms under control.

Posts.Title: Had my ORP yesterday...

Posts.Content: Glad that part is over. Tip of the old unit felt like it was trying to pee razor blades in the recovery room but some stronger meds got me past that. Been for two walks already and it is still before noon. Just waiting to pass gas now. Reading others experiences on this forum is really helping me get through this.

Posts.Title: Had my ORP yesterday...

Posts.Content: First post, hope I am doing this right. Today at my pre-surgical screening for ORP, I was told of two different forms of post-op pain mangement. One was the Patient Controlled Analgesia (PCA) pump, the other was Spinal Anesthesia. They were both explained to me and I was given a small pamphlet on each. I was also told that they would ask me what I wanted on the day of the operation. I have read some pros and cons for each, but I don't care for the idea of something else hanging from me (PCA) after the operation. Nor do I like the idea of a needle in the spine. So I thought I would post on here and hope to get some real info from those that have been there, done that.

Posts.Title: Pain Management right after surgery

Posts.Content: Thanks MM. After the 6 week PSA results came in, I pre-arranged a meeting with my RO to take place just after the 10 week test. With the positive margins and high PSA, I was expecting SRT or HT plus SRT was in my future. Strange thing is that the results of this latest PSA test hit me harder than the original cancer diagnosis. Just really expected it to be lower not higher. I was just reading about neoadjuvant ADT last night, maybe I jinxed myself. Thanks again for he reassuring words.

Posts.Title: I wasn't ready for this...

Posts.Content: Allen, Jim, Chuck, MF, and RobLee, thanks for the replys and info. Knowing that, as RobLee says "none of this is abnormal" has really helped reduce the stress level. And thank you Rob for the link to that article, it also was a help. Originally Posted by RobLee This is the stage 3 part, and is likely the result of your positive margins noted in your sig. It's all there... "Staging is pT3/pN0 Extraprostatic extension present, nonfocal (established, extensive), right side Apical resection margin is bilaterally involved by invasive carcinoma Right and left seminal vesicles not involved by adenocarcinoma" As I understand it, the "extensive extraprostatic extension" part means that the cancer had spread outside your prostate capsule. Fortunately your lymph nodes and seminal vesicles were apparently not involved. I don't know how that actually causes your body to produce the PSA, but apparently it does. Here is a good article on extraprostatic extension http://www.harvardprostateknowledge....-prostatectomy ... The author states that 10-20% of RP patients have positive margins. I think you're handling it pretty well. You knew there would be radiation afterwards, and this is why. Similar situation for me. I too see my RO next week, and I have been afraid that my PSA might start to climb but have been lucky so far. You will pull thru this just fine. There are a few of us T3 guys here and they're all still posting. Keep your spirits up and remember that none of this is abnormal. If anything, the fact that your PSA has already begun to rise will likely mean that you will probably need to begin radiation sooner rather than later. Good luck!

Posts.Title: I wasn't ready for this...

Posts.Content: I know my 6 weeks post-op PSA of 0.53 was bad enough, but was expecting the 10 week post-op PSA to be somewhat lower. It's not. My PSA is now 0.65! Now I don't know what to think. In all the books I read, have not seen anything about PSA this high and rising this soon after surgery. I know radiation is in my future and have an appointment next week with a radiation oncologist that specializes in PC. I like to be prepared for these meetings and have an understanding of what's happening with my PC and a list of questions before the meeting. But now I just don't know what I am in for. Can somebody give me an idea of what is happening please?

Posts.Title: Mr. Foley, how I hate thee

Posts.Content: I got my post op pathology report from my surgon yesterday and it wasn't what I was hoping to hear. In short, positive margin. The stats are listed below in my signiature. He suggested I start thinking about radiation treatments, adjuvant or salvage. He said it is too early to decide, but I should start my research. My first post op PSA test will be in about 6 weeks from now (about 9 weeks post op). So I would like to hear from others that have faced this decision and learn from them about their choice and expieriences. Many thanks to the members that take the time to post all the helpful info on this forum. It is much appreciated.

Posts.Title: PSA Six weeks after surgery.
